title: How many verb tenses are there in English? - Anna Ananichuk

multiple-choice.question: How many different tenses are there in a language like English?
What is the continuous or progressive aspect in English?

options.label: B
options.text: Describes actions that are ongoing at the time of reference.

options.label: D
options.text: Describes actions that are not specified as continuous or discrete.

multiple-choice.question: What is the perfect aspect in English?

options.label: D
options.text: Describes actions that are not specified as continuous or discrete.

multiple-choice.question: What is the simple aspect in English?

options.label: C
options.text: Describes actions that are not specified as continuous or discrete.

multiple-choice.question: What is the future perfect progressive aspect in English?

options.label: A
options.text: Describes a completed part of a continuous action.

options.label: D
options.text: Describes an action that will be achieved by a specific point in the future.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key insight to understanding the different tenses in English?

options.label: A
options.text: Each sentence takes place in a specific moment.

options.label: B
options.text: Each sentence describes a continuous action.

options.label: C
options.text: Each sentence describes a completed action.

options.label: D
options.text: Each sentence describes an action that is not specified as continuous or discrete.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the way English and Japanese describe time?

options.label: A
options.text: English has more grammatical tenses than Japanese.

options.label: B
options.text: Japanese has more grammatical tenses than English.

options.label: C
options.text: English distinguishes past from non-past, while Japanese does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Japanese distinguishes past from non-past, while English does not.

options.label: A
options.text: English has more grammatical tenses than Mandarin Chinese.

options.label: B
options.text: Mandarin Chinese has more grammatical tenses than English.

options.label: C
options.text: English distinguishes past from non-past, while Mandarin Chinese does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Mandarin Chinese has no verb tenses at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the way English and Yagwa describe time?

options.label: A
options.text: English has more grammatical tenses than Yagwa.

options.label: B
options.text: Yagwa has more grammatical tenses than English.

options.label: C
options.text: English splits past tense into multiple degrees, while Yagwa does not.

options.label: D
options.text: Yagwa splits past tense into multiple degrees, while English does not.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the way English and other languages describe time?

options.label: A
options.text: English has more grammatical tenses than other languages.

options.label: B
options.text: Other languages have more grammatical tenses than English.

options.label: C
options.text: English describes time in a different way than other languages.

options.label: D

title: Why do mirrors flip horizontally (but not vertically)?

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why mirrors appear to flip things horizontally?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our eyes are horizontal in our heads.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the image in the x direction.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the image in the z direction.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the image in the y direction.

multiple-choice.question: When you look at a word in a mirror, why does it appear to be flipped horizontally?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the mirror is flipping the word in the x direction.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the mirror is flipping the word in the z direction.

options.label: C
options.text: Because you are presenting the word to the mirror in a way that flips it horizontally.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the word in the y direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a horizontal flip and a vertical flip?

options.label: A
options.text: A horizontal flip is when you flip an image in the x direction, and a vertical flip is when you flip an image in the y direction.

options.label: B
options.text: A horizontal flip is when you flip an image in the z direction, and a vertical flip is when you flip an image in the x direction.

options.label: C
options.text: A horizontal flip is when you flip an image in the z direction, and a vertical flip is when you flip an image in the z direction.

options.label: D
options.text: A horizontal flip is when you flip an image in the y direction, and a vertical flip is when you flip an image in the x direction.

multiple-choice.question: Why do we think that mirrors flip things horizontally when they really don't?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our eyes are horizontal in our heads.

options.label: B
options.text: Because most of the words we see in the mirror are on t-shirts and we don't think of them as horizontally flipped.

options.label: C
options.text: Because most of us are left and right symmetric.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the mirror is reflecting the image in the x direction.

title: Can you solve the dark coin riddle? - Lisa Winer

multiple-choice.question: What was the task that the traveler had to accomplish in order to leave the dungeon?

options.label: A
options.text: Find the legendary dungeon containing the stash of ancient Stygian coins.

options.label: B
options.text: Separate the Stygian coins into two piles so that each has the same number of coins facing silver side up.

options.label: C
options.text: Solve the puzzle given by the eccentric wizard who owns the castle.

options.label: D
options.text: Count exactly 20 silver-side-up coins in the pile.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the traveler try to remember where the silver-facing coins were, but it was hopeless?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there were hundreds of coins in front of them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the torches suddenly blew out and they were left in total darkness.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the coins felt the same on both sides.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the traveler was not paying attention.

multiple-choice.question: What can the traveler do to separate the coins into two piles with the same number of silver-side-up coins?

options.label: A
options.text: Count the number of silver-side-up coins and move that number of coins to a new pile.

options.label: B
options.text: Take 20 coins one by one and flip each one of them over.

options.label: C
options.text: Try to remember where the silver-facing coins were before the darkness.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a coin to determine the way to the next adventure.

multiple-choice.question: What is a complementary event?

options.label: A
options.text: When a coin has two possible options: gold side up or silver side up.

options.label: B
options.text: When a coin only has one possible option: gold side up.

options.label: C
options.text: When a coin has no options: it is either gold side up or silver side up.

options.label: D
options.text: When a coin has multiple options: it can be gold side up, silver side up, or neither.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the solution of taking 20 coins and flipping them over work?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the number of silver-facing coins in the original pile is always equal to the number of silver-facing coins in the new pile.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the number of gold-facing coins in the new pile is always equal to the number of silver-facing coins in the original pile.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the traveler is very lucky.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the traveler flips all the coins in the new pile over?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of silver-facing coins in the new pile decreases.

options.label: B
options.text: The number of gold-facing coins in the new pile increases.

options.label: C
options.text: The number of silver-facing coins in both piles is the same.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the solution of taking 20 coins and flipping them over a simple solution?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a complex mathematical solution.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a simple mathematical solution.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a solution that requires a lot of luck.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a solution that requires a lot of effort.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the website that the traveler recommends for interactive puzzles?

options.label: A
options.text: You get access to a large number of puzzles.

options.label: B
options.text: You get access to a large number of puzzles and you can also create your own puzzles.

options.label: C
options.text: You get access to a large number of puzzles and you can also get a 20% discount on the annual premium subscription fee.

options.label: D

title: What are mini brains? - Madeline Lancaster

multiple-choice.question: What is a brain organoid?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of stem cell that can develop into any tissue in the body.

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of lab-grown neurons and other brain tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of brain disease that affects millions of people.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of brain surgery that is performed to remove tumors.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult for scientists to observe the human brain in action?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is too small to see.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is too complex to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is shielded by our thick skulls and swaddled in layers of protective tissue.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is too expensive to study.

multiple-choice.question: What is an undifferentiated stem cell?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of stem cell that can only develop into a specific tissue.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of stem cell that can develop into any tissue in the body.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of stem cell that can only develop into a specific organ.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of stem cell that can only develop into a specific cell type.

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists grow brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a combination of sugars, proteins, vitamins, and minerals.

options.label: B
options.text: By using a special gel to simulate embryonic tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: By using a warm incubator set at body temperature and a bit of motion to mimic blood flow.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only be grown to a certain size.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only be grown from a specific type of stem cell.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only be grown using a specific type of gel.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only be grown in a specific type of incubator.

multiple-choice.question: Can brain organoids think for themselves or develop consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, they can think and develop consciousness.

options.label: B
options.text: No, they cannot think or develop consciousness.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the type of brain organoid.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why brain organoids cannot think or develop consciousness?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not organized like a real brain.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they do not have blood vessels to feed them.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not able to interact with the outside world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: They can be grown to a large size.

options.label: B
options.text: They can be grown from any type of stem cell.

options.label: C
options.text: They can be used to study the development of the human brain.

options.label: D
options.text: They can be used to study the development of any type of tissue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in growing brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the perfect combination of sugars, proteins, vitamins, and minerals.

options.label: B
options.text: Growing them to a large size.

options.label: C
options.text: Organizing them like a real brain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of studying brain organoids?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand what makes the human brain unique.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand what makes other types of brains unique.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how to grow larger brain organoids.

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how to use brain organoids to treat brain diseases.

title: Could we cure aging during your lifetime?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of scientists working on healthspan extension?

title: Why you should define your fears instead of your goals

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's approach to dealing with stress and anxiety?

options.label: A
options.text: He practices meditation and deep breathing exercises.

options.label: B
options.text: He uses the tool of stoicism to separate what he can control from what he cannot control.

options.label: C
options.text: He focuses on setting goals and achieving them.

options.label: D
options.text: He avoids making decisions and taking action.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's definition of stoicism?

options.label: A
options.text: A philosophy that emphasizes the importance of emotions and feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: A way of life that focuses on being passive and accepting of circumstances.

options.label: C
options.text: A comprehensive system for training oneself to separate what one can control from what one cannot control.

options.label: D
options.text: A set of rules and regulations to follow in order to be successful.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's "fear-setting" exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: A method of visualizing success and achieving goals.

options.label: B
options.text: A way of writing down and addressing one's fears and anxieties.

options.label: C
options.text: A technique for developing self-discipline and willpower.

options.label: D
options.text: A process for making decisions and taking action plans.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "Prevent" column in the author's "fear-setting" exercise?

options.label: A
options.text: To list potential outcomes and consequences of taking action.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify potential risks and obstacles to overcome.

options.label: C
options.text: To brainstorm ways to prevent or mitigate potential negative outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a plan of action to achieve success.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's mantra, as shared by Jerzy Gregorek?
Who is Jerzy Gregorek, and what is his background?

options.label: A
options.text: A four-time world champion in Olympic weightlifting, who has also written a bestselling book on stoicism.

options.label: B
options.text: A four-time world champion in Olympic weightlifting, who is a published poet and has a background in politics.

options.label: C
options.text: A four-time world champion in Olympic weightlifting, who is a published poet and has a background in politics and was part of the Solidarity movement in Poland.

options.label: D
options.text: A four-time world champion in Olympic weightlifting, who is a published poet and has a background in politics and was part of the Solidarity movement in Poland, and now lives in Woodside, California.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's takeaway from Jerzy Gregorek's story?

options.label: A
options.text: That stoicism is only for successful people.

options.label: B
options.text: That stoicism is a way of life that can help one overcome adversity.

options.label: C
options.text: That Jerzy Gregorek is a great example of someone who has applied stoicism in their life.

options.label: D
options.text: That Jerzy Gregorek's story is an inspiration to apply stoicism in one's life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's definition of "fear-setting" in relation to stoicism?

options.label: A
options.text: A way of visualizing success and achieving goals.

options.label: B
options.text: A method of identifying and addressing one's fears and anxieties.

options.label: C
options.text: A technique for developing self-discipline and willpower.

options.label: D
options.text: A process for making decisions and taking action.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message about stoicism?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a philosophy that emphasizes the importance of emotions and feelings.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a way of life that focuses on being passive and accepting of circumstances.

options.label: C
options.text: That it is a comprehensive system for training oneself to separate what one can control from what one cannot control.

options.label: D
options.text: That it is a tool for making better decisions and overcoming obstacles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final thought on stoicism?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is a philosophy that is only for the elite.

options.label: B
options.text: That it is a way of life that can help one overcome adversity and achieve success.

options.label: C
options.text: That stoicism is a tool that can be applied in all areas of life.

options.label: D
options.text: That stoicism is a philosophy that emphasizes the importance of emotions and feelings.

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: How often should you get a flu shot? - Melvin Sanicas

multiple-choice.question: Why do we need a new flu vaccine every year?

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: The flu virus has a genetic code that allows it to mutate more quickly than many other viruses.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Because the flu virus has a genetic code that allows it to mutate more quickly than many other viruses.

multiple-choice.question: What is herd immunity, and how does the flu vaccine help protect others?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
